text: in
1914 Ella wheeler Wilcox published a
poem that began to sin by silence when
we should protest makes cowards out of
men today as we Face our futures over
100 years later I draw on her wise words
to speak speak to you above all else
about the dangers of
Silence I fully realize the irony of
encouraging 900 Harvard mbas to speak
their
minds at first glance it might seem that
for the past two years we've done little
else we've had the privilege of being
overeducated by professors and over
served by
bartenders stocking up on prophetic
strategies and passport stamps and even
Resort ording to technical question
sheep shots just to get in that one last
time but it is the responsibility of the
informed to speak up when we can make a
difference and HBS class of
2017 what a difference we can
make in recent years we have seen how
drastically the share of voices in this
country and the World At Large have
shifted more people are speaking up
different people are speaking up and in
many more
ways and if we correctly appreciate
voice as a form of value the
implications of this shift are
staggering ever more intertwined
economic and political interests affect
the societies we live in the businesses
we work in and the people we
love so whether you're an HKS jointy or
a plain old one degree capitalist
without a conscience we are all beholden
to the world around us
as Future Leaders we will likely hold
positions where our voices will have
outsized influence on our
surroundings so opinions on current
events are not
optional identities will not wait to be
formed we must Define and defend
ourselves with thoughts and words and
expect others around us to do the
same I do not make this plea to belittle
quiet as a necessary Counterpoint or to
demote action as a necessary
result but to admit that at times we
fail to summon the courage to simply
speak some might think it's wholly
unnecessary to encourage mbas to speak
their minds or that like any good
consultant I'm just telling you
something you've heard before but with
fancier words and that I'll probably
send you an invoice after I've
sufficiently worn you down all forms of
payment are accepted but I prefer claims
on the future earnings of anyone in cbcr
but even among so many
extroverts I think there's more here to
explore in fact this speech itself is an
exercise in self-commitment in holding
myself accountable for as long as
YouTube and its balanced thoughtful
commenters shall
live because in my experience speaking
up has not always come
naturally I challenged myself to think
through this topic because my struggle
with it is both L held and
ongoing as a gay 15-year-old in the
conservative Midwest silence smothered
me I remember realizing that more than
the way I walked or the way I dressed it
was really the way I talked that
prompted people to label
me more specifically it was the way I
said the letter s
my S is cilent or characterized by a
hissing sound and I thought if I could
mask my S then I could mask
myself so first I tried changing the way
I pronounced
words I like sports should be I like
sports which I um totally definitely
do after I very obviously failed at this
I then tried to figure out how I could
speak without saying s so much how to
substitute words without that one pesky
little letter for example instead of
salutations section mates such a strong
sweat we're sporting in this surprise
Summer Sun I might say hi I'm
warm needless to say a brevity did not
come easily to me and neither did hiding
my
identity it was not until years years
later that I realized how much I had
been silencing
myself I also realized that the
processes of discovering oneself and
revealing oneself run
parallel some of my thoughts didn't
crystallize until I pushed myself to say
them out
loud but that is not a dynamic unique to
me I didn't want to face confrontation
for what I was saying or how I was
saying it
isn't that something we all can relate
to there are ideas inside each of us
that should be articulated both
endorsements and oppositions that should
be brought
forth and for one reason or another they
aren't so then why should we fight
against the human instinct to protect
ourselves because as this institution
has reminded us time and again that's
what leaders who make a difference in
the world do
those topics we were taught not to
discuss at the dinner table money
politics religion well money politics
religion class color weakness
wants this country seems the most
divided it's been in any of our
lifetimes and it will stay that way as
long as people avoid engaging with other
points of
view now is not the time to shy away
from topics that might make us
uncomfortable
or opinions that might make us
unpopular but of course there are times
when we all do exactly that try to think
of a time when you didn't stand up for
an idea or opinion or a person maybe it
was
yourself and try to identify exactly why
you
didn't the reason might be like all
things when you're cold called and
haven't read the case
contextual but it's probably something
far more
Universal
fear there are times we don't speak up
for fear of being
redundant because we think what we
believe has already been voiced that our
opinion is the opinion that the silent
majority will carry the
day and many times it does and we face
no
consequence but there in lies the danger
if we all remain silent on topics for
which We Believe others will speak on
our
behalf there will come a day when no one
does there are times when we don't speak
up for fear of being
inappropriate some of us find it easier
to raise the Counterpoint sitting around
a conference room table others around a
dining room table but whether you're
more at home surrounded by reassuring
facts and figures or by friends who
sympathize with our exact points of view
we must fight the urge to Reserve our
voices for the spaces where we feel most
comfortable we cannot separate our lives
into personal opinions and professional
actions that do not
align we cannot insulate ourselves from
the world around us by retreating to a
corner
office and there are times where we
don't speak up for fear of being
wrong because we're waiting for the
perfect data the perfect moment the
perfect
answer but there is real value in
expressing
uncertainty there may not be scribes in
every one of our future conference rooms
but in the real world questions still
count for something and by asking
questions by exposing oursel in this way
we encourage others to do the
same it is better to engage imperfectly
then abstain indefinitely
now I could stop here but um well let's
let that man in the first row doze off
for a few more minutes oh um that's my
dad can someone wake him up okay great
thank you and uh furthermore if I were
to stop here my message would be
incomplete this mindset should not
prioritize our opinions leaders opinions
above anyone
else's rather it should set the norm for
all if we value our own voices enough to
use them as Tools of Change then we must
also listen to the voices of others and
enable them to do just the
same while it's easy to listen to those
who agree with us some of my most potent
memories of classmates speaking up were
those who totally shut me
down remember when that section made
blew up classroom discussion by
questioning an assumption the rest of us
had taken for granted or when someone
disagreed with you and actually changed
your mind
the Great Moments in HBS classrooms
reveal the empathy of our education
taking the point of view of a
protagonist their personal baggage
professional background and present
challenges and charting a path
forward but the best moments in the HBS
classroom also take advantage of the
empathy amongst 90 different
perspectives within the
classroom I hope we don't let that
lesson leave us once we cross this
threshold we must listen to those who
speak up both alongside and against
us we must Embrace dissenters even when
it seems
inconvenient we
must value the voices of our doubters as
much as those of our
Champions this is our responsibility not
just to ourselves as people but to our
identities As
Leaders listening is good for
maintaining perspective listening is
good to combat consensus to dispel group
think to burst bubbles be they on
financial markets or national
politics listening is also good if
you're an asarone environmentalist
climbing Everest with a bunch of section
mates still gunning for Baker scholar
you know just
theoretically so
today when we gather to celebrate our
commencement to thank all of those who
helped us get here and most importantly
to amass the most Instagram live likes
of Our Lives thus far let's hold oursel
responsible to a new normal for
mbas no matter what critics might say
regardless of your gender race Faith
your cilent s or the metallic grade of
your passport each of us has the agency
to Define Our Life and
Legacy HBS class of
2017 I urge you not to sin by silence
find your voice share your voice and
welcome the voices of
others there are times when this might
be offbrand but it will certainly keep
us on track thank you
